statement.text: The NPV Decision Rule: Accept all independent projects with NPV > 0. When choosing among mutually exclusive projects, select the one with the highest NPV. This rule maximizes shareholder wealth.
statement.formal: Decision(Project) = Accept if NPV > 0; Reject if NPV < 0; Indifferent if NPV = 0

explanation.intuition: A positive NPV means the project creates value - the present value of cash inflows exceeds the cost. This increases shareholder wealth by exactly the NPV amount (in present value terms). A negative NPV destroys value.
explanation.theoretical_foundation: The NPV rule is derived from the wealth maximization objective of the firm. It correctly accounts for: (1) time value of money, (2) risk (through discount rate), (3) all cash flows over project life, and (4) opportunity cost of capital.

why_npv_beats_other_metrics.vs_payback: NPV considers all cash flows and time value; payback ignores later cash flows and doesn't discount
why_npv_beats_other_metrics.vs_irr: NPV gives actual value created; IRR can give multiple or no solutions, and fails for non-conventional cash flows
why_npv_beats_other_metrics.vs_accounting_return: NPV uses cash flows not accounting profits; accounts for time value which accounting ignores

explanation.mutually_exclusive_projects: When projects compete (can only do one), choose the highest NPV. Don't choose highest IRR or shortest payback - NPV directly measures value creation.

independent_vs_dependent.independent: Accept all with NPV > 0 (if no capital constraints)
independent_vs_dependent.contingent: Only accept B if A also accepted (use combined NPV)

decision_algorithm.single_project:
if NPV > 0: accept
elif NPV < 0: reject
else: indifferent
decision_algorithm.mutually_exclusive: choose project_j where NPV_j = max(NPV_1, NPV_2, ..., NPV_n)

learning_objectives: State the NPV decision rule accurately
Apply the rule to single and multiple project decisions
Explain why NPV maximizes shareholder wealth
Distinguish between independent and mutually exclusive projects
common_errors: Choosing highest IRR project instead of highest NPV when mutually exclusive
Accepting projects with NPV < 0 because they have positive IRR
Forgetting that NPV = 0 means earning exactly the required return (acceptable)
Mixing up independent vs. mutually exclusive project evaluation
practice_problems: Three independent projects have NPVs of $5k, -$2k, and $8k. Which should be accepted?
Two mutually exclusive projects: A (NPV=$10k, IRR=25%) vs. B (NPV=$12k, IRR=20%). Which to choose?
